newsitem.title: USA: U.S. to sell $7 bln of inflation-protected notes.
newsitem.headline: U.S. to sell $7 bln of inflation-protected notes.

text.p: Treasury will sell $7 billion of inflation-indexed 10-year notes in its initial auction of the new security next Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said on Tuesday.

The sale amount was the final detail that Treasury had to announce about the new security that it initially proposed in May last year. The 10-year note, sold in minimum denominations of $1,000, is designed to keep pace with inflation so that its value upon maturity is not eaten away by rising prices.
At a press conference, Rubin said he expected the new type of security to have a major impact on financial markets and to benefit both investors and the government.

"I believe this is an extremely important development for the United States' financial markets," Rubin said. "It has the potential to increase the rate of savings and it will in time also enable tht Treasury to borrow at a lower cost of money."
Rubin said other maturities of inflation-portected securities will be offered in future, but said he was unsure whether they will carry a longer or shorter term than the initial 10-year note.
In response to questions, Rubin said he expected financial markets to begin when-issued trading in the new securities immediately. They will be sold on a quarterly basis, he said.

Rubin emphasized the Treasury has "a strong, long-term commitment to this product" and said the decision to sell $7 billion worth of the 10-year notes was intended to demonstrate that commitment. It also was intended to ensure that enough were in the market for trading to occur, he said.
But he noted the size of the first isue was "small relative to the debt structure of the U.S. government," so that there was little need to cut back on other debt issues.
"Over time, we will have to deal with the question of where we see this as fitting in the yield curve of our debt structure," Rubin acknowledged, adding: "We have some thoughts on that, obviously."
The inflation-protected 10-year notes will pay interest twice a year, on July 15 and Jan 15. Next week's sale will raise cash for the government rather than pay down existing debt.
They will be auctioned in a single-price auction format, or a so-called Dutch auction.
Rubin said the new securities might spawn big changes in financial markets by encouraging investors to think more about real rates of return.
That, in turn, might make intermediaries like mutual funds to start offering competitive products like indexed annuities, Rubin suggested.
